entry.title: SAP BTP: Looking good this Summer with smart new G2 badges
entry.content:
A little over six months have passed since my last blog on the topic of G2 badges, but with summer now here for many of us, it seems appropriate that G2 have awarded SAP BTP some shiny new and very smart looking badges, and don‚Äôt they look great?

Now great looking badges are one thing, but what do they actually mean? G2 of course associates badges directly with the type and quality of feedback that they obtain through customers reviews, and for the types of badges awarded to SAP BTP the meanings are clearly defined:

  • Momentum Leader: Products in the Leader tier in the Momentum Grid¬Æ rank in the top 25% of their category's products by their users
  • Grid Leader: Products in the Leader quadrant in the Grid¬Æ Report are rated highly by G2 users and have substantial Satisfaction and Market Presence scores
  • Users Love Us badge: Earned after collecting 20 reviews with an average rating of 4.0 stars

The SAP BTP team is of course delighted to continue to receive these badges of recognition from G2, and thankful for the feedback left by many customers which has led to these being awarded.

What do customers say about SAP BTP?

Recent feedback from SAP customers reveals a range of different ways in which they are using SAP BTP to help solve business or process issues, from automation and AI to application development and clean core initiatives, all of which help to deliver value to their organizations. A full list of customer reviews can be found at the SAP BTP landing page on the G2 website. But here‚Äôs a snapshot of what some of these reviews say when asked what their favourite thing is about SAP BTP:

‚ÄúThe best I like is we can build the apps side by side, automate various business process and integrate seamlessly with SAP and non SAP applications without disturbing the core system, which makes core system not only making clean core but also to make the upgrades easy!‚Äù

(User review by an enterprise customer, May 2025)

‚ÄúWe can create custom applications (in a supply chain use case) with robust UI and design frame works for meeting unsolved business use cases‚Ä¶Built Goods receipt and Quality process automation tool for our warehouse / distribution center‚Ä¶building tool to manage supply chain flows - Logistics flows, Physical flows and Financial flows.‚Äù

(User review by a small business customer, May 2025)

‚ÄúPretty easy! It‚Äôs a comprehensive cloud platform that offers a variety of services and capabilities. Some key aspects that users may find appealing include its ability to accelerate digital transformation.‚Äù

(User review by enterprise customer, May 2025)

As ever, my thanks to the many SAP BTP customers who choose to leave reviews on the G2 platform, and for making it possible for us to be recognized through the G2 badges.

Wishing you all a super summer ahead, and I hope to be back later in the year to share more news about G2 customer review of SAP BTP with you.

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Automating iFlow Documentation with SAP Integration Suite and Gemini AI
entry.content:
üß≠ Introduction

Documenting integration flows in SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) is a critical but often tedious task. Manual documentation is time-consuming, error-prone, and difficult to maintain‚Äîespecially in dynamic environments where iFlows evolve frequently.

To address this, an automated documentation generator was developed, that utilizes the OData APIs from SAP Integration Suite in combination with Gemini AI. This solution dynamically extracts iFlow metadata and resources, processes them into a structured format, and sends them to Gemini AI to generate a comprehensive technical specification document. The result is a scalable, secure, and intelligent system that can document any iFlow in a subaccount on-demand or on a schedule.

üèóÔ∏è Architectural Overview

The architecture orchestrates several components of the SAP Integration Suite and Gemini AI to automate the documentation process. Below is a visual representation of the architecture:

 

üîÅCPI Integration Flow (iFlow)

At the heart of the solution is a CPI Integration Flow that orchestrates the entire automation. This iFlow can be triggered:

  • Periodically (e.g., every Week)
  • On-demand (via manual or external trigger)

The iFlow performs the following:

  • Retrieves iFlow metadata and resources
  • Prepares and formats the data
  • Sends it to Gemini AI
  • Stores the generated documentation in a Datastore

üåêAccessing SAP Integration Suite OData APIs

The iFlow uses OData APIs exposed by the SAP Integration Suite to access:

  • iFlow Metadata (design-time artifacts)
  • Resources such as:
    • Groovy scripts
    • XSLT mappings
    • EDMX schemas
  • You could try out those endpoints here: Business Accelerator Hub

üîêAuthentication

  • The iFlow uses OAuth2 client credentials to authenticate against the SAP BTP XSUAA service.
  • A Process Integration Runtime (PIR) service instance is bound to the subaccount.
  • Oauth Client Credential is created in the Security Materials.

üåêSAP CPI Odata Interfaces

  • iFlow Metadata: {{CPI_Tenant_URL}}/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='{Id}',Version='{Version}')/$value
    • Returns a Zip folder containing the flow's configuration file, ".iflw" file.
    • The retrieved data includes: 
      • Flow Steps: Activities like Router, Content Modifier, Join, Splitter, Gather, etc.
      • Sequence Flows: Logical connections between steps
      • Metadata: Flow name, version, and other properties
  • Resource List: {{CPI_Tenant_URL}}/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='{Id}',Version='{Version}')/Resources
    • This endpoint returns a list including all resources utilized within the IFlow
    • The retrieved data includes resources such as Groovy scripts, XSLT mappings, EDMX files.
    • Sample Request:  https://sandbox.api.sap.com/cpi/api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id=IntegrationFlowWithConfiguration,Version=active)/Resources

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.zip.ZipEntry;

def Message processData(Message message) {
	
	def body = message.getBody(InputStream.class);
	def zipStream = new java.util.zip.ZipInputStream(body);
	def stringBuffer = new StringBuffer();

	ZipEntry entry=zipStream.getNextEntry();
    byte[] buf=new byte[1024];
    while (entry != null) {
      if (entry.getName().endsWith(".xml")) {
        ByteArrayOutputStream out=new ByteArrayOutputStream();
        int n;
        while ((n=zipStream.read(buf,0,1024)) > -1) {
          out.write(buf,0,n);
        }
       	message.setBody(new String(out.toByteArray()));
      	break;
      }
      zipStream.closeEntry();
      entry=zipStream.getNextEntry();
    }

	return message;
}

üßπ Pre-processing for Gemini AI

Before sending the data to Gemini AI, the iFlow performs several pre-processing steps:

üß© Structuring the Input

  • The metadata and resources are wrapped in XML under <Resources> and <FlowSteps> tags.
  • The entire structure is Base64 encoded to ensure safe transmission.
  • The encoded data is embedded in a JSON payload with system instructions.

üß† Instruction Format

{
  "system_instruction": {
    "parts": [
      {
        "text": "You are an SAP CPI Developer... create a technical specification document."
      }
    ]
  },
  "contents": [
    {
      "parts": [
        {
          "inline_data": {
            "mime_type": "text/plain",
            "data": "${property.Base64Body}"
          }
        },
        {
          "text": "Here is the configuration... provide a detailed explanation..."
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

ü§ñSending to Gemini AI

The structured payload is sent to Gemini AI using its REST API:

üåêAPI Call

  • Endpoint: https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.0-flash:generateContent
  • Method: POST
  • Authorization: x-goog-api-key added to request's headers 
  • Headers:
    • Content-Type: application/json
    • x-goog-api-key: {{Gemini_API_Key}}
  • For more information regarding Gemini APIs check Gemini Api Documentation.
  • Sample Request Body:
{
    "contents": [
      {
        "parts": [
          {
            "text": "How does AI work?"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
  • Sample Response:

            "text": "AI, or Artificial Intelligence, is a broad field of computer science that aims to create machines that can perform tasks that typically require human intelligence. This includes things like learning, problem-solving, decision-making, understanding language, recognizing patterns, and even creativity.\n\nWhile \"AI\" can encompass many approaches, the dominant paradigm today is **Machine Learning (ML)**, and more specifically, **Deep Learning (DL)**. Here's a simplified breakdown of how it generally works:\n\n### The Core Ingredients of AI (especially Machine Learning)\n\n1.  **Data:** This is the \"fuel\" for AI. AI systems learn from vast amounts of data, much like humans learn from experience. This data can be anything:\n    *   **Labeled Data:** Images with descriptions (\"cat,\" \"dog\"), text with sentiment (\"positive,\" \"negative\"), or numerical tables with outcomes. This is used for **supervised learning**.\n    *   **Unlabeled Data:** Just raw images, text, or numbers without specific tags. This is used for **unsupervised learning** (finding patterns) or **reinforcement learning** (trial and error).\n\n2.  **Algorithms:** These are the \"recipes\" or \"instructions\" that the AI uses to learn from the data and make decisions. They are mathematical models and computational procedures. Examples include:\n    *   **Neural Networks:** Inspired by the human brain, these are layers of interconnected \"neurons\" that process information. Deep Learning uses *many* layers.\n    *   **Decision Trees:** Flowchart-like structures for making decisions.\n    *   **Regression Models:** Used for predicting continuous values (e.g., house prices).\n    *   **Clustering Algorithms:** Grouping similar data points together.\n\n3.  **Computing Power:** Training complex AI models, especially deep learning ones, requires immense computational resources.\n    *   **GPUs (Graphics Processing Units):** These are particularly good at parallel processing, making them ideal for the heavy mathematical computations involved in training neural networks.\n    *   **Cloud Computing:** Services like AWS, Google Cloud, and Azure provide scalable computing power for AI development.\n\n### How AI Learns (The Process)\n\nLet's use a common example: training an AI to recognize cats in photos.\n\n1.  **Data Collection & Preparation:**\n    *   You gather thousands, even millions, of images.\n    *   For supervised learning, you label each image: \"This is a cat,\" \"This is a dog,\" \"This is a car.\" This creates the dataset.\n\n2.  **Model Training (The Learning Phase):**\n    *   You feed this labeled dataset into a chosen algorithm (e.g., a deep neural network).\n    *   The algorithm starts by making random \"guesses\" about what constitutes a cat.\n    *   It then compares its guesses to the actual labels. If it misidentifies a cat as a dog, it incurs an \"error\" or \"loss.\"\n    *   Through a process called **backpropagation** (in neural networks), the algorithm adjusts its internal parameters (like the \"weights\" and \"biases\" of the connections between neurons) slightly to reduce that error.\n    *   This process is repeated thousands or millions of times, with the algorithm continuously refining its internal understanding of what patterns correlate to \"cat-ness.\"\n    *   Essentially, it learns to identify specific features (e.g., pointed ears, whiskers, specific fur patterns) and combine them to accurately classify an image as a \"cat.\"\n\n3.  **Model Evaluation:**\n    *   After training, the model is tested on a *separate* set of data it has never seen before (the \"test set\"). This ensures it has truly learned and isn't just memorizing the training data.\n    *   Its performance is measured by metrics like accuracy, precision, and recall.\n\n4.  **Inference (Prediction/Deployment):**\n    *   Once the model is trained and evaluated, it's ready for use.\n    *   When you feed a *new, unseen* image to the trained AI model, it applies the patterns it learned during training to predict whether the image contains a cat, dog, or something else. This prediction is usually very fast.\n\n### Key Branches and Concepts in AI\n\n*   **Machine Learning (ML):** The core idea is that computers learn from data without being explicitly programmed for every possible scenario.\n    *   **Supervised Learning:** Learning from labeled examples (e.g., predicting house prices based on features and past sales data).\n    *   **Unsupervised Learning:** Finding hidden patterns or structures in unlabeled data (e.g., segmenting customers into groups based on their purchasing behavior).\n    *   **Reinforcement Learning:** An agent learns by interacting with an environment, receiving rewards for good actions and penalties for bad ones (e.g., training an AI to play chess or control a robot).\n\n*   **Deep Learning (DL):** A *subset* of Machine Learning that uses Artificial Neural Networks with many layers (\"deep\" networks). This has been particularly successful in tasks like image recognition, natural language processing, and speech recognition due to its ability to learn complex patterns directly from raw data.\n\n*   **Natural Language Processing (NLP):** Enables computers to understand, interpret, generate, and manipulate human language (e.g., chatbots, translation services, spam filters).\n\n*   **Computer Vision (CV):** Allows computers to \"see\" and interpret visual information from images and videos (e.g., facial recognition, self-driving cars, medical image analysis).\n\n*   **Robotics:** Involves the design, construction, operation, and use of robots. AI often powers the \"brain\" of robots, enabling them to perceive their environment, navigate, and make decisions.\n\n### In Summary:\n\nAI, especially through Machine Learning and Deep Learning, works by providing algorithms with massive amounts of data. These algorithms then learn complex patterns and relationships within that data. Once trained, they can apply this learned \"knowledge\" to new, unseen data to make predictions, classify information, generate content, or make decisions, effectively mimicking aspects of human intelligence."

  • The response contains a text block with the generated documentation.
  • The iFlow uses XPath and Content Modifier steps to extract the relevant content.
  • The final output is stored for future access.

üíæOutput Storage

The AI-generated documentation is stored in a data store, which can be:

  • CPI‚Äôs internal datastore
  • External database (e.g., SAP HANA, PostgreSQL)

This allows teams to retrieve and review documentation at any time.

Step-by-Step guide on how to Implement

N.B: Please Externalize all Parameters, URLs, and Keys when possible to avoid exposing them to AI model.

The Integration flow is divided into 4 processes:

 

1. Main Integration Process:

Steps:

1. Timer Start:

The flow runs once deployed

2. Set Parameters:

Both Flow name represented by its ID and flow version of the flow that we want to create a TSD for are specified, additionally ExceptionLogging property is set to yes if we want to log error details.

Property NameSource TypeValueDescription
FlowNameConstant{{Flow_ID}}Specify Flow ID
FlowVersionConstant{{Flow_Version}}Specify Flow Version
ExceptionLoggingConstant{{logException}}use Yes if you want to log exceptions

3. Parallel multicast:

A parallel multicast is used to execute the local integration processes "Get Flow Resources" and "Get Flow Steps" at the same time.

4. Process Calls and Gather

Each of the parallel branches includes a Process Call component to Call the local Integration Processes.

5. Join and Gather

A join component is used to bring the messages from different routes into a single one, and the gather aggregates the different payloads into a single payload.

6. Gemini AI process Call:

The returned response from the previous Process Calls is sent to the Gemini AI Process call for further processing and sending to Gemini AI.

7. Save response:

A Datastore is used to saves the response returned by the Gemini Process Call, it sets the ID of the message to the name of the IFlow. 

8. Exception Handling:

An exception subprocess is added to all Local Integration processes to handle exceptions.

Code:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
def Message processData(Message message) {
  // get a map of properties
  def map = message.getProperties();
  def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
  // get an exception java class instance
  def ex = map.get("CamelExceptionCaught");
  def exceptionLogging = map.get("ExceptionLogging");
  if (exceptionLogging != null && exceptionLogging == "Yes" && ex != null) {
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("Exception Body ", body, "text/plain");
    // an http adapter throws an instance of
    // org.apache.camel.component.ahc.AhcOperationFailedException
    if (ex.getClass().getCanonicalName().equals(
            "org.apache.camel.component.ahc.AhcOperationFailedException")) {
      // save the http error response as a message attachment
      messageLog.addAttachmentAsString(
          "http.ResponseBody", ex.getResponseBody(), "text/plain");
      // copy the http error response to an exchange property
      message.setProperty("http.ResponseBody", ex.getResponseBody());
      // copy the http error response to the message body
      message.setBody(ex.getResponseBody());
      // copy the value of http error code (i.e. 500) to a property
      message.setProperty("http.StatusCode", ex.getStatusCode());
      // copy the value of http error text (i.e. "Internal Server Error") to a
      // property
      message.setProperty("http.StatusText", ex.getStatusText());
    }
  }
  return message;
}

 

2. Get Flow Steps

1. Get Flow Configuration File:

  • Method:  GET
  • Address: {{CPI_Tenant_URL}}/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='${property.FlowName}',Version='${property.FlowVersion}')/$value
  • Authentication: Client Secret Credential
  • For creating the Oauth 2.0 client secret credential please follow this Post.

2. Zip Splitter:

Zip splitter is used to iterate on the files within the zip file returned by the previous step and selects only the Flow Configuration File based on the file name pattern ‚Äú.iflw‚Äù

3. Remove Namespace XSLT

This step is used to remove unwanted namespaces from the IFlow's configuration file using xslt mapping file

Code:

<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"><xsl:output method="xml" version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" />

        <xsl:template match="*">

                <xsl:element name="{local-name()}" >

                        <xsl:apply-templates select="@* | node()"/>

                </xsl:element>

        </xsl:template>

</xsl:stylesheet>

4. XML Modifier

Remove xml declaration and external DTDs

5. Zip Splitter Gather:

A gather is used to aggregate the payloads from the zip splitter into a single payload.

 

3. Get Flow Resources

1.Get Resources List:

  • Method:  GET
  • Address: {{CPI_Tenant_URL}}/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='${property.FlowName}',Version='${property.FlowVersion}')/Resources
  • Authentication: Client Secret Credential
  • For creating the Oauth 2.0 client secret credential please follow this Post.

2. Remove Namespaces

This step is used to remove unwanted namespaces from the IFlow's configuration file using xslt mapping file

XSLT : 

<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"><xsl:output method="xml" version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" />

        <xsl:template match="*">

                <xsl:element name="{local-name()}" >

                        <xsl:apply-templates select="@* | node()"/>

                </xsl:element>

        </xsl:template>

</xsl:stylesheet>

3. Iterate over Returned Resource List

General splitter is used to iterate over resources using xpath '//entry' as each resource is enclosed with "entry" XML tag as shown in the sample request mentioned in the "Endpoints Section".

4. Extract Resource name and  Resource type

Those values are extracted to be used in retrieving the resource in subsequent step using Xpaths.

Exchange Properties: 

NameSource ValueData Type
Name//Namejava.lang.String
ResourceType//ResourceTypejava.lang.String
Url//entryIdjava.lang.String

 

5. Get single resource value

  • Method:  GET
  • Address: {{CPI_Tenant_URL}}/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='${property.FlowName}',Version='${property.FlowVersion}')/Resources(Name='${property.Name}',ResourceType='${property.ResourceType}')/$value
  • Authentication: Client Secret Credential
  • For creating the Oauth 2.0 client secret credential please follow this Post.

6. Set Resource body by enclosing the resource value by its name

<${property.Name}>
    ${in.body}
</${property.Name}>

7. Gather Resources:

A gather step is used to aggregate all retrieved resources into a single payload.  

8. Content Modifier: 

A content modifier is used to add XML tags for Gemini to identify the resources.

Sample:

<Resources>
    ${in.body}
</Resources>

 4. Gemini AI utilization

1. Base-64 Encoding Step:

The XML message constructed at the previous step is encoded using 64-Base to be sent to the AI model as plain text.

2. Formatting Body

Remove unwanted characters Remove new lines, and carriage return

Code: 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
 def Message processData(Message message) {
     def body = message.getBody(String);
     String backspace = '\n' as char;
     String enter = '\r' as char;
     body = body.replace(backspace, "");
     body = body.trim();
     body = body.replace(enter, "");
     body = body.trim();
     message.setBody(body);
    return message;
 }

3. Add headers and Create body

Creates the JSON structure payload that is send to the Gemini AI API to generate the documentation and adds a Message Header "Content-Type" with value "application/json".

For more information regarding Gemini APIs check Gemini Api Documentation.

Body set to Expression: 

{
    "system_instruction": {
      "parts": [
        {
          "text": "You are an SAP CPI Developer, your main role is to get SAP CPI Iflows configuration and form them create a technical specification document."
        }
      ]
    },
    "contents": [
      {
        "parts": [
          {"inline_data": {"mime_type": "text/plain", "data": "${property.Base64Body}" } },
          {"text": "Here is the configurations create a Tsd providing a detailed explanation on what this iflow does and steps involved and documentation of scripts and mappings, you will find in the text the following an xml tag definition this includes the flow steps and another tag Resources which includes all scripts, mappings used are attached"}
        ]
      }
    ]
  }

4. POST  request to Gemini API

  • Method:  POST
  • Address: https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.5-flash:generateContent
  • Authentication: added as a request header "x-goog-api-key"
  • Headers: 
    • Content-Type: application/json
    • x-goog-api-key: {{Gemini_API_Key}}
  • For creating your api key follow this Gemini API Key.

5. JSON to XML Converter

This step is used to convert the JSON body to XML to be able to extract response using Xpath.

6. Extract documentation from Payload:

Xpath is used to extract the response from the payload and stored in an Exchange Property "response" and within the same content modifier the body is set to ${property.response}

Deployment and Document Generation

The Flow was deployed setting the Parameters to flow name and version of this IFlow.

Here was the response saved to the DataStore:

The iflow automates the process of extracting iflow configuration and resources, sending them to the Gemini AI model, and receiving a generated TSD as output. The process comprises the following steps:

Configuration Retrieval: Configuration details of the Iflow including FlowSteps and Resources like scripts and mappings are retrieved.

7. Security Considerations

Sensitive information like CPI credentials and the Gemini API key must be stored securely using CPI's secure parameter store.
Access to the iflow and its configuration should be restricted to authorized personnel only.
8. Deployment

The iflow can be deployed through the SAP CPI web UI or using the Cloud Management API.
Ensure all externalized parameters are configured appropriately.
9. Monitoring

Monitor the iflow execution logs in CPI for any errors or performance bottlenecks.
Track datastore entries in IflowDocumentation datastore for completed TSD generation runs.
10. Notes

The quality of the generated TSD depends on the Gemini AI model.
The accuracy of the generated documentation relies on the configurations of the flowsteps.
This document serves as a guide for developers to support and enhance the integration.

Benefits and Use Cases

Here‚Äôs how the solution delivers real business value across several dimensions:

‚úÖBenefits of Automated iFlow Documentation

‚è±Ô∏è Time Saved

  • Manual documentation of iFlows typically involves opening each flow, inspecting steps, copying scripts, and writing descriptions‚Äîthis can take hours per flow.
  • Your automated approach reduces this to minutes, or even seconds, by:
    • Programmatically retrieving metadata and resources
    • Using Gemini AI to generate structured documentation instantly
  • This is especially impactful in environments with dozens or hundreds of iFlows.

üìãConsistency in Documentation

  • Manual documentation often varies in structure, terminology, and depth, depending on who writes it.
  • Gemini AI ensures:
    • Standardized format across all iFlows
    • Consistent terminology and technical descriptions
    • Repeatable output, regardless of who triggers the flow
  • This improves readability, maintainability, and collaboration across teams.

üßæ Use in Audits, Onboarding, and Handovers

  • Audits: Automatically generated documentation provides a clear, traceable record of integration logic and configurations, helping meet compliance requirements.
  • Onboarding: New developers or integration consultants can quickly understand existing flows without needing to reverse-engineer them.
  • Handovers: When projects transition between teams or vendors, having up-to-date technical specs ensures smooth knowledge transfer and reduces risk.

Conclusion and Next Steps

In this project, we built an automated solution that leverages the SAP Integration Suite OData APIs and Gemini AI to generate technical documentation for any iFlow within a subaccount. The solution:

  • Dynamically retrieves iFlow metadata and resources (Groovy scripts, XSLT, EDMX)
  • Prepares and formats the data into a structured context
  • Sends it to Gemini AI to generate a detailed technical specification
  • Stores the output in a persistent data store for future reference

This approach significantly reduces manual effort, ensures consistency, and supports better documentation practices across integration landscapes 

üôåTry It, Share It, Connect!

If you found this solution helpful or inspiring, here‚Äôs how you can take the next step:

  • Customize it to fit your documentation standards or integration landscape.
  • Experiment with different AI prompts or formats to tailor the output.

üí¨ Share Your Feedback

  • Did it save time? Improve clarity? Spark new ideas?
  • Drop your thoughts in the comments or reach out directly.

Your feedback and collaboration can help evolve this into an even more powerful tool for the SAP Integration community.

entry.title: Using SAP managed iFlows for Time series data Integration in SAP IBP ‚Äì Part 1 - Reading data
entry.content:
Introduction

You can use SAP Cloud Integration as a middleware to read and write Timeseries as well as Master data between SAP IBP and any other application. The IBP team provides an SAP managed package which you can reuse in your custom integration to extract as well as insert or update time series data in IBP. This blog explains the steps needed to enable this package in your SAP Cloud Integration Instance. It mainly focuses on reading data from SAP IBP and explains the different payloads you have to build to reuse this package in your own custom iFlows.

Reusable iFlows

In the next blog, I explained how one can write data to SAP IBP.  Here we focus on reading data. SAP IBP comes with a communication scenario SAP_COM_0931. This exposes a set of RFC function modules which can be consumed in SAP Cloud Integration via a communication user.  A set of iFlows are delivered by SAP IBP which consumes these RFC calls to read and write data bi-directionally. These are called the reusable iFlows and they can be imported into your SAP CI instance via the Discovery mechanism in Cloud Integration.

Fig.1 Discovering the SAP IBP Content in Integration Suite

On the landing page of the SAP Integration Suite open the Discover menu on the left hand side and click on Integrations. In the right hand side you would see the search option. Filter your search for the key word IBP. You would see the SAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows. You can import them to your instance. You can build you own wrapper iFlows around these reusable iFlows to focus on your IBP content. The rest of this blog describes how to build these wrappers.

Fig.2. High level view of using custom content to read data from SAP IBP using the reusable iFlows

This blog would help you when you are creating your Custom Integration package. An example iFlow package ‚Äì SAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows Example, is also available which can be imported inside your instance.

Prerequisite

This integration pattern would work for you only when you are using SAP IBP ver 2411 and above. Make sure you have a valid SAP Cloud Integration license. The following steps are mandatory.

  1. In SAP IBP, Create a communication arrangement for SAP_COM_0931. Also create a communication system and a user. The credentials are needed for the BTP destination in your sub account.
  2. In your SAP Integration Suite instance, discover the SAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows and copy them to your instance.
  3. In your BTP Sub account, create a new destination with the following configuration:
    1. Name: e.g. SAP_IBP_Instance
    2. Type:  RFC
    3. Proxy Type: Internet
    4. Alias User: IBP Communication user
    5. Password:  IBP Communication user password
    6. Additional Properties:
      1.  jco.client.serialization_format  : columnBased
      2.  jco.clients.tls:trust                        : 1
      3.  jco.client.wshost                            : < SAP IBP -api Domain name>
      4.  jco.client.wsport                            :443

           Save the Destination Configuration and check the connection.

Create a Package in the SAP Cloud Integration under Integration -> Design.

Reading data from SAP IBP

Create your own package which would contain all your iFlows to read and write data between SAP IBP and your external application. Let‚Äôs start by creating an iFlow that would read data from SAP IBP. This iFlow would use the Process Direct interfaces defined in the SAP IBP ‚Äì reusable Integration Flows. Let‚Äôs assume that you would be calling this iFlow from your external application or a tool like Postman or Bruno.

The end-to-end main flow would look like this below

Fig.3. An example main iFlow 

The main flow is exposed with an HTTP Adapter. One can set the end point and later invoke this iFlow with a JSON payload. Hence the first atom is an Analyse Payload Groovy Script. Here we can analyse and store the properties such as IBP Destination, Job name, field list we want to read, the payloads we want to send to IBP as well as the master data prefix and type or key figure data along with the planning area. One can also add a flag to state the data consistency at this point and check with a router if all input properties are available and valid or not. The Groovy script below would help prepare to analyse the properties,

// Analyse the inbound payload to read master data from SAP IBP 
def Message handlePayloadForRead_MDs(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.io.Reader);
    def input = new JsonSlurper().parse(body);    
   
    message.setProperty("payloadIsOk", "yes")
      
    if(!input?.IBPDestination || input.IBPDestination.toString().trim().isEmpty() ){
        message.setProperty("payloadIsOk", "no")
    } else {
         message.setProperty("IBPDestination",  input.IBPDestination); 
    }   
    
    if(!input.IBPMasterDataPrefix || input.IBPMasterDataPrefix.toString().trim().isEmpty() ){
        message.setProperty("payloadIsOk", "no")
    } else {
         message.setProperty("IBPMasterDataPrefix",  input.IBPMasterDataPrefix); 
    } 
    
    if(!input.IBPMasterDataType || input.IBPMasterDataType.toString().trim().isEmpty() ){
        message.setProperty("payloadIsOk", "no")
    } else {
         message.setProperty("IBPMasterDataType",  input.IBPMasterDataType); 
    } 
    
    if(!input.IBPQuerySelect || input.IBPQuerySelect.toString().trim().isEmpty() ){
        message.setProperty("payloadIsOk", "no")
    } else {
         message.setProperty("IBPQuerySelect",  input.IBPQuerySelect); 
    }   
    
    message.setProperty("IBPKey", input.IBPMasterDataType)
    message.setProperty("IBPJobName", "ReadMasterData") 
    message.setProperty("IBPDetailedTrace", true)
    return message;
}

Initialize a read query

As an example, in the above code snippet, we are checking for values we need for an XML payload to initialize the following read query  in the body of a Content Modifier atom.

Master data:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<IBPReads>
  <IBPRead Key="${property.IBPKey}"
    TypeOfData="MASTERDATA"
    MasterDataPrefix="${property.IBPMasterDataPrefix}"
    MasterDataCoreType="${property.IBPMasterDataType}"
    Destination="${property.IBPDestination}"
    Select="${property.IBPQuerySelect}"/>
</IBPReads>

Key-figure Data: 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<IBPReads>
  <IBPRead 
    Key="${header.IBPReadKey}"
    TypeOfData="KeyFigures"
    PlanningArea="SAPIBP1"
    Destination="${header.IBPReadDestination}"
    TimeAggregationLevel="2"
    Select="PRDID,LOCID,CUSTID,TSTFR,PERIOD_LEVEL_2,FINALDEMANDPLANNINGQTY"
    PackageSizeInMB = "50"/>
</IBPReads>

It is also possible to set a filter. An example would be: Filter=" PRDID eq '1010'" . Here the Filter is an attribute. The response for this call would be something like below,

<IBPRead xmlns:multimap="http://sap.com/xi/XI/SplitAndMerge"
         Destination="As defined in the BTP Destinations for RFC"
         Filter="PRDID eq '1010'"
         Index=""
         Key="Read MD"
         Limit="2147483647"
         MasterDataCoreType="PRODUCT"
         MasterDataPrefix="DB1"
         MaximumThreads="4"
         OrderBy=""
         PackageSizeInRows="49"
         Rows="49"
         SQLStatement="SELECT PRDID, BRAND, PRDDESCR, UOMDESCR FROM (SELECT PRDID, BRAND, PRDDESCR, UOMDESCR FROM SAPSOPG100.SOPMD_DB1PRODUCT WHERE PRDID = ‚Äò1010‚Äô LIMIT 2147483647)"
         Select="PRDID,BRAND,PRDDESCR,UOMDESCR"
         Status="FETCH_DATA"
         TypeOfData="MasterData"
         UUID="*******07084B77E190051FAB9E*****"/>

You will know the number of records based on your selection criteria from this response payload. The XML element Rows would give the total number of rows based on the selection criteria in the select and filter attributes.  The UUID in the above payload is important. It can be stored in as message property and later used to read the data. It acts as a transaction ID for reading. To initialize a read query, I created a local integration process which looks like this,

Fig.4. Local integration process for initializing a query 

The process direct would call the SAP IBP reusable iFlow at the address: SAP_IBP_Read_-_Initialize

READ data

When we read key figure or master data in IBP, we do this asynchronously in packages. If you have less number of records, you can read data in one single package (for example, the above payload does that). But if you have large volumes of data to be written, then multiple packages are created in the backend. You can define a package size.

The following XML payload is sent to the Read process direct at the address SAP_IBP_Read_-_Fetch_Data

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> 
<IBPRead xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
    UUID="="*******07084B77E190051FAB9E*****" 
    Key="Read MD" 
    PackageSizeInRows="49"
    ParallelThread="" 
    Offset=""/>

The XML has the following attributes :

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

UUID

A unique key valid in all the steps of the asynchronous reading process

This value is generated in the backend

Key

A Job name

‚ÄúRead MD‚Äù

PackageSizeInRows

The number of records you want to read in one package

5000

Offset

To support the top-skip mechanism

0 ‚Äì do not hard code it. Use a variable to skip the records you read.

The PackageSizeInRows attribute would define the number or rows read in one batch or package. The Rows element from the response would give the total number of records found based on the selection criteria. Based on these two properties, one can loop the reading process. A top skip mechanism can be implemented. The reading loop can be exited once all the records were read from the row count. An offset XML attribute can be updated to skip the number of records currently read. The following XSLT snippet helps to implement the moving offset to enable the skip and the localIBPReadPackageSizeInrows attribute would help in implementing the $top function.

<xsl:template match="/">
        <!-- Ensure all values are numbers -->
        <xsl:variable name="numberOfRows"
           select="if (normalize-space($IBPReadRows) = '') then 0 else number($IBPReadRows)"/>
        <xsl:variable name="localIBPReadPackageSizeInRows"
            select="if (normalize-space($IBPReadPackageSizeInRows) = '')
                    then $numberOfRows
                    else number($IBPReadPackageSizeInRows)"/>

        <xsl:variable name="offset"
            select="if (normalize-space($IBPReadOffset) = '') then 0 else number($IBPReadOffset)"/>

        <xsl:variable name="newOffset"
            select="round($offset + $localIBPReadPackageSizeInRows)"/>
            
<xsl:value-of select="cpi:setProperty($exchange, 'IBPReadOffset', format-number($newOffset, '#'))"/>   

        <xsl:variable name="fetchFinished" select="if ($newOffset lt $numberOfRows) then 'false' else 'true'"/>  

<xsl:value-of select="cpi:setProperty($exchange, 'IBPReadFetchFinished', $fetchFinished)"/>         

        <xsl:copy-of select="."/>

    </xsl:template>

The above XSLT is implemented in the Process Fetch atom which is an XSLT mapping step in the below local integration process.

Fig.5. Local integration process to read data. Should be called in a loop.

Once you call this process direct, an RFC function module is internally called by the reusable iFlows. It would return a XML payload with additional attributes like below  

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<IBPReadMasterDataPRODUCT>
  <item>
    <PRDID>1010</PRDID>
    <BRAND>DEMO2</BRAND>
    <PRDDESCR>DEMO2 product</PRDDESCR>
        ...........
  </item>
</IBPReadMasterDataPRODUCT>

Response from IBP using this approach would be in XML. If you like to convert it to a JSON payload, you can use an atom ‚Äì convert XML to JSON.  

Conclusion

In this blog, I tried to give a step by step explanation on how to build your own custom iFlow which can be used to consume the Reusable iFlows from SAP IBP to read data. In another blog, explain with similar steps - how to write data to SAP IBP.

entry.title: Using SAP managed iFlows for Time series data Integration in SAP IBP ‚Äì Part 2 - Writing data
entry.content:
Introduction

You can use SAP Cloud Integration as a middleware to read and write Timeseries as well as Master data between SAP IBP and any other application. The IBP team provides a SAP managed package which you can reuse in your custom integration to extract as well as insert or update time series data in IBP. This blog explains the steps needed to enable this package in your SAP Cloud Integration Instance. It also explains the different payloads you have to build to reuse this content in your own custom iFlows.

Reusable iFlows

SAP IBP comes with a communication scenario SAP_COM_0931. This exposes a set of RFC function modules which can be consumed in SAP Cloud Integration via a communication user.  A set of iFlows are delivered by SAP IBP which consumes these RFC calls to read and write data bi-directionally. These are called the reusable iFlows and they can be imported into your SAP CI instance via the Discovery mechanism in Cloud Integration. On the landing page of the SAP Integration Suite open the Discover menu on the left hand side and click on Integrations. In the right hand side you would see the search option. Filter your search for the key word IBP. You would see the SAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows. You can import them to your instance. You can build you own wrapper iFlows around these reusable iFlows to focus on your IBP content. The rest of this blog describes how to build these wrappers.

Fig.1. High level overview of writing data to SAP IBP from an external application.

This blog would help you when you are creating your Custom Integration package. An example iFlow package ‚Äì SAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows Example, is also available which can be imported inside your instance.

Prerequisite

This integration pattern would work for you only when you are using SAP IBP ver 2411 and above. Make sure you have a valid SAP Cloud Integration license. The following steps are mandatory.

  1. In SAP IBP, Create a communication arrangemen for SAP_COM_0931. Also create a communication system and a user. The credentials are needed for the BTP destination in your sub account.
  2. In your SAP Integration Suite instance, discover the SAP IBP ‚Äì Reusable Integration Flows and copy them to your instance.
  3. In your BTP Sub account, create a new destination with the following configuration:
    1. Name: e.g. SAP_IBP_Instance
    2. Type:  RFC
    3. Proxy Type: Internet
    4. Alias User: IBP Communication user
    5. Password:  IBP Communication user password
    6. Additional Properties:
      1.  jco.client.serialization_format : columnBased
      2.  jco.clients.tls:trust                       : 1
      3.  jco.client.wshost                          : < SAP IBP -api Domain name>
      4.  jco.client.wsport                          : 443

             Save the Destination Configuration and check the connection.

  1. Create a Package in the SAP Cloud Integration under Integration -> Design.

Writing data to SAP IBP

Create your own package which would contain all your iFlows to read and write data between SAP IBP and your external application. Lets start by creating an iFlow that would write data into SAP IBP. This iFlow would use the Process Direct interfaces defined in the SAP IBP ‚Äì reusable Integration Flows. Lets assume that you would be calling this iFlow from your external application or a tool like Postman or Bruno.

The end to end main flow would look like this below

Fig.2 Example main flow for writing data to SAP IBP

The main flow is exposed with an HTTP Adapter. One can set the end point and later invoke this iFlow with a JSON payload. Hence the first atom is an Analyse Payload Groovy Script. Here we can analyse and store the parameters such as IBP Destination, Job name, field list we want to write, the payload we want to send to IBP as well as the master data prefix and type or key figure data along with the planning area. One can also add a flag to check the payload consistency at this point and check with a router if the payload is valid or not. For example, we need the IBP Destination name which is configured in the BTP destination. We can check for this by using a simple if statement like this,

message.setProperty("payloadIsOk", "yes")
if(!input?.IBPDestination || input.IBPDestination.toString().trim().isEmpty() ){
        message.setProperty("payloadIsOk", "no")
   } else {
         message.setProperty("IBPDestination",  input.IBPDestination);
    }

In the above code snippet, we are checking for the IBP Destination in the inbound payload using the key IBPDestination. If the value is empty or not available, a property called payloadisOk is set to ‚Äúno‚Äù condition. Such a check can be repeated for all mandatory key value pairs or JSON arrays such as the payload you want to send to IBP. Later the flag payloadIsOk can be checked in the router atom using the following Non-XML condition: ${header.payloadIsOk} != 'no'.

The JSON payload can also be converted to a XML structure using the following snippet:

def writer = new StringWriter()
def xml = new MarkupBuilder(writer)
        xml.IBPPayload {
            input.IBPPayload.each { item ->
                IBPItem {
                    item.each { key, value ->
                        "${key}"(value)
                    }
                }
            }
        }

        def xmlString = XmlUtil.serialize(writer.toString())
        message.setProperty("IBPPayload", xmlString)

Create Batches

When we write key figure or master data in IBP, we do this asynchronously in batches. If you have less number of records, you can write data in one single batch. But if you have large volumes of data to be written, then multiple packages are created in one batch or the flow is called multiple times creating multiple batches. The following steps are reommended while working with these reusable iFlows,

  • Specify a planning area. Do not use multiple planning areas ‚Äì it is currently not supported.
  • Planning area field is mandatory for writing Key figure values.
  • Only one version of the planning area is currently supported. If you do not specify the planning area version, data would be written to the Baseline version of the planning area.
  • Prepare the Write batch payload and the call the process direct from the reusable iflow.

The following XML Attributes are mandatory while creating a batch for writing master data.

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

Key

A batch key valid in all the steps of the asynchronous process

‚ÄúMyKey‚Äù

Name

A Job name

‚ÄúWrite Master data‚Äù

Destination

IBP destination as defined in the BTP sub account

‚ÄúIBP_Production_Instance‚Äù

Command

RFC operation with the data

‚ÄúINSERT_UPDATE‚Äù

Other commands you can use are REPLACE, DELETE in the above attribute. The following XML Attributes are optional while creating a batch for writing master data.

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

DetailedTrace

For debugging

true or false

ProcessUnchangedData

For post processing

true or false

The detailed trace attribute would generate logs that can be used while debugging an integration flow. The Boolean value toggles this setting. The ProcessUnchangedData would instruct the post processing job to process unchanged data ‚Äì irrespective of the global configuration setting. The Boolean value toggles this setting. If not provided, the global parameter setting is considered. A Sample XML payload for creating batches to write master data would look like this,

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<IBPWriteBatches>
    <IBPWriteBatch 
        Key="${header.IBPKey}"
        Name="${header.IBPJobName}"
        Destination="${property.IBPDestination}"
        Command="${header.IBPCommand}"
        DetailedTrace="${header.IBPDetailedTrace}"
        ProcessUnchangedData="${header.IBPProcessUnchangedData}"/>
</IBPWriteBatches>

The following XML Attributes are mandatory while creating a batch for writing key figure data.

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

Key

A batch key valid in all the steps of the asynchronous process

‚ÄúMyKeyfigureKey‚Äù

Name

A Job name

‚ÄúWrite Keyfigure data‚Äù

Destination

IBP destination as defined in the BTP sub account

‚ÄúIBP_Production_Instance‚Äù

Command

RFC operation with the data

‚ÄúINSERT_UPDATE‚Äù

PlanningArea

Name of the IBP Planning area

‚ÄúSAPIBP1‚Äù

The following XML Attributes are optional while creating a batch for writing master data.

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

PlanningAreaVersion

Version of the above planning area

Default is the Baseline version if left empty

DetailedTrace

For debugging

true or false

ProcessUnchangedData

For post processing

true or false

A Sample XML payload for creating batches to write master data would look like this,

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<IBPWriteBatches>
    <IBPWriteBatch 
        Key="${header.IBPKey}"
        Name="${header.IBPJobName}"
        Destination="${property.IBPDestination}"
        Command="${header.IBPCommand}"
        PlanningArea="${property.IBPPlanningArea}"
        DetailedTrace="${header.IBPDetailedTrace}"
        ProcessUnchangedData="${header.IBPProcessUnchangedData}"/>
</IBPWriteBatches>

In the above example payloads, I am sending a JSON payload to the iFlow and validating it on the first groovy script atom. Here the mandatory fields are checked and stored in the message properties and header. Later I can use them to create the corresponding payloads in a content modifier, Groovy Script or a XSLT transformation atom. Such a combination can be self-contained in a local integration process and called from the main integration process. An example of such a local integration process can look like,

Fig. 3 Local integration flow to create batches.

Once the payload is prepared to create a batch, a request-reply atom should be used with a Process Direct adapter. This adapter should be configured to call the address SAP_IBP_Write_-_Create_Batches. This address is defined in the Reusable integration flow from SAP IBP to create a batch in IBP.

Once you call this process direct, an RFC function module is internally called by the reusable iFlows. It would return a XML payload with additional attributes in the IBPWriteBatch element. You can store these values using a xpath in a content modifier or an XSLT or a Groovy script. The XML structure would look like, 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
  <multimap:Messages xmlns:multimap="http://sap.com/xi/XI/SplitAndMerge">
    <multimap:Message1>
      <IBPWriteBatch
        CallerId="AstalaVistaCaller_can_be_any"
        Command="INSERT_UPDATE"
        Destination="IBP_Production_Instan"
        Id="6440"
        Index="1"
        Key="MyKeyfigureKey"
        Name="Write Keyfigure data"
        PlanningArea="SAPIBP1"/>
    </multimap:Message1>
</multimap:Messages>

If you open the Data Integration Jobs application in SAP IBP, you can cross check for the Job ID 6440. This is a sequential number that is generated in SAP IBP.

POST data to IBP

Using the batch id that was generated in the previous step, one can write data in packages. One can also instruct the package size and create a logic to loop over till all the data is written to IBP.

STEPS: Prepare the XML Payload and then call the Process Direct from the reusable iFlow

The following XML Attributes are mandatory while preparing the XML payload for posting master data to IBP.

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

Id

The Batch ID that was generated in the previous step from IBP

‚Äú6440‚Äù

BatchKey

A batch key valid in all the steps of the asynchronous process

‚ÄúMyKey‚Äù

FileName

A Job name

‚ÄúWrite Master data‚Äù

Destination

IBP destination as defined in the BTP sub account

‚ÄúIBP_Production_Instance‚Äù

MasterDataPrefix

Prefix of the master data

‚ÄúAB1‚Äù

MasterDataType

Master data type

‚ÄúPRODTYPE‚Äù

FieldList

List of elements that belong to the master data type

‚ÄúPRODTYPEID,PRODUCTDIM,PRODTYPEDESC‚Äù

Item

Each record that you want to write to IBP must be enclosed in this item element

<item> <PRODTYPEID>885522</PRODTYPEID> <PRODUCTDIM>Cat1</PRODUCTDIM><PRODTYPEDESC>Category 1 product</PRODTYPEDESC> </item>

The important thing to observe in the above table is the Field list and the Item elements. The field list contains the root attributes in a comma separated string. The item element contains the value of the root elements enclosed in the root attribute as element name. The following XML Attributes are optional while creating a batch for writing master data.

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

DetailedTrace

For debugging

true or false

ProcessUnchangedData

For post processing

true or false

The following XSLT snippet contains a simple construct for creating a XML payload for writing master data.

<IBPWriteMasterData
  Id="{$batchId}"
  MasterDataType="{$IBPMasterDataType}"
  MasterDataPrefix="{$IBPMasterDataPrefix}"
  Destination="{$IBPDestination}"
  FileName="{$IBPJobName}"
  FieldList="{$IBPFieldList}"
  BatchKey="{$IBPJobName}">                               

  <xsl:for-each select="$IBPPayloadXML/*/IBPData"> 
    <item>
      <xsl:copy-of select="*"/>
    </item>
  </xsl:for-each>
</IBPWriteMasterData>

A Sample XML payload with 1 record would look as below,

<IBPWriteMasterData
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
  Id="6440"
  MasterDataType="PRODTYPE"
  MasterDataPrefix="AB1"
  Destination="IBP_Production_Instance"
  FileName=" Write Master data "
  FieldList=" PRODTYPEID,PRODUCTDIM,PRODTYPEDESC "
  BatchKey="MyKey ">
  <item>
    <PRODTYPEID>885522</PRODTYPEID>
    <PRODUCTDIM>Cat1</PRODUCTDIM>
    <PRODTYPEDESC>Category 1 product</PRODTYPEDESC>
  </item>
</IBPWriteMasterData>

The following XML Attributes are mandatory while posting keyfigure data to IBP.

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

Id

The Batch ID that was generated in the previous step from IBP

‚Äú6441‚Äù

BatchKey

A batch key valid in all the steps of the asynchronous process

‚ÄúMyKeyfigureKey‚Äù

FileName

A Job name

‚ÄúWrite Keyfigure data‚Äù

Destination

IBP destination as defined in the BTP sub account

‚ÄúIBP_Production_Instance‚Äù

TimeDisaggregationLevel

Time level of the key figure data

1

FieldList

List of elements that belong to the master data type

‚ÄúPRDID,LOCID,CUSTID,PROMQTY,KEYFIGUREDATE‚Äù

Item

Each record that you want to write to IBP must be enclosed in this item element

<item><PRODID>885522</PRODID><LOCID>FP1</LOCID><CUSTID>1010</CUSTID><PROMQTY>100</PROMQTY><KEYFIGUREDATE>2025-07-15</KEYFIGUREDATE></item>

A Sample XML payload for writing key figures with 1 record would look as below,

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<IBPWriteKeyfigures xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
  Id="6441"
  Destination="IBP_Production_Instance"
  FileName="Write Keyfigure data"
  FieldList="PRDID,LOCID,CUSTID,PROMQTY,KEYFIGUREDATE"
  TimeDisaggregationLevel="1"
  BatchKey="MyKeyfigureKey">
  <item>
    <PRODID>885522</PRODID>
    <LOCID>FP1</LOCID>
    <CUSTID>1010</CUSTID>
    <PROMQTY>100</PROMQTY>
    <KEYFIGUREDATE>2025-07-15</KEYFIGUREDATE>
  </item>
</IBPWriteKeyfigures>

The actual IBP payload can also be combined with a JSON structure if needed. One can use a XSLT transformation to create this payload for pure XML. Groovy can be used to create both XML as well as a combination of XML and JSON payloads. The steps can be created in side a local integration process and called from the main process. It can look like below,

Fig.4 Local integration flow to write data. Can be called in a loop.

Once the payload is prepared to write data, a request-reply atom should be used with a Process Direct adapter. This adapter should be configured to call the address SAP_IBP_Write_-_Post_Data. This address is defined in the Reusable integration flow from SAP IBP to create a batch in IBP. Once the RFC request is made, the response from the reusable iflow would contain the original request as well as the following response while writing key figure data.

<IBPWriteKeyfigures xmlns:multimap="http://sap.com/xi/XI/SplitAndMerge" Status="OK">
  <Request>‚Ä¶ original payload ‚Ä¶</Request>
  <Response>
    <Status>OK</Status>
    <Messages>
      <Message Type="Information">Initialization of file <<filename>> is completed.</Message>
    </Messages>
  </Response>
</IBPWriteKeyfigures>

 Post processing 

Once the data is posted to IBP, a post processing job is triggered which would validate the master data as well as the consistency of the key figure value as defined in the planning area. One can initiate a post processing check using the following XML mandatory XML elements for Master data

XML Attribute

Description

Example Value

Key

A batch key valid in all the steps of the asynchronous process

‚ÄúMyKey‚Äù

Name

A Job name

‚ÄúWrite Master data‚Äù

Destination

IBP destination as defined in the BTP sub account

‚ÄúIBP_Production_Instance‚Äù

Command

RFC operation with the data

‚ÄúINSERT_UPDATE‚Äù

Id

Batch ID generated while creating batches

‚Äú6440‚Äù

A Sample payload would look like this,

<IBPWriteBatches>
  <IBPWriteBatch
    Command="INSERT_UPDATE"
    Destination=" IBP_Production_Instance"
    Id="6440"
    Key=" MyKey "
    Name=" Write Master data "
    DetailedTrace="true"
    ProcessUnchangedData="false"/>
</IBPWriteBatches>

Sample payload for Post processing key figure batch  would look like below

<IBPWriteBatches>
  <IBPWriteBatch
    Command="INSERT_UPDATE"
    Destination=" IBP_Production_Instance "
    Id="6441"
    Index="1"
    Key=" MyKeyfigureKey "
    Name="My Keyfigure data"
    PlanningArea=" SAPIBP1"
    DetailedTrace="true"
    ProcessUnchangedData="false"/>
</IBPWriteBatches>

These XML payloads can be generated using a Content Modifier Atom. Once the payload is generated in the body, a request-reply atom can be used with a Process Direct adapter. The address in the adapter would be: SAP_IBP_Write_-_Process_Posted_Data. This would close the data integration for writing data into IBP. These steps can be built in a local integration process. Such a process can look like,

Fig. 5 Local integration flow for Post processing

The above process can be called from the main integration flow.

Conclusion

In this blog I explained how you can leverage the SAP managed reusable iFlows from IBP to write data. In another blog, I explained how to read data using the same reusable package from SAP. Hope these blogs come handy for any developer to build your own custom iFlows for reading or writing data from SAP IBP to external systems.

Step-2: Implementing layer-1-Routing layer:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.util.XmlSlurper

Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(String) // Get XML as a string
    def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body) // Parse XML

    def targetRoute = ""

    // Check the root element or a specific tag (adjust as needed)
    if (xml.name() == "Products") {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_products_layer-2"
    } else if (xml.name() == "Suppliers") {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_suppliers_layer_2"
    } else {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_books_layer_2"
    }

    message.setProperty("routeTo", targetRoute) // Store the route in a property
    return message
}

Implementation: This is the Routing layer paste the groovy code that i given above .

Declare the content modifier like below add Exchange properties like below

Implement the content modifier as like the below

entry.title: Improving Exception Handling using Generative AI in SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI/CPI)
entry.content:
When it comes to integrating different systems within a business, SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI/CPI) capability in Integration Suite Service of SAP BTP is a go-to tool. However, as these integrations become more complex, handling exceptions - errors and issues, efficiently becomes increasingly important. Generative AI can help businesses tackle these challenges by automating error detection and providing useful insights. Here‚Äôs what you can gain from using AI:

  • User - Friendly Error Messages: Sender systems can receive clear, simple error messages that anyone can understand, not just tech experts.
  • Better Monitoring: You can see these user-friendly error message logs in SAP CI/CPI dashboards, making it easier to track and fix issues.
  • Identify Error Causes: AI can help identify why an error occurred, offering a better understanding of the issue.
  • Suggest Solutions: It can also suggest ways to address and fix the error.
  • Simplify Troubleshooting: Both tech and non-tech staff can troubleshoot errors more easily.
  • Reduce Resolution Time: Speed up the process of solving errors.
  • Prepare for the Future: The insights gained can improve how errors are classified and handled in the future by agentic AIs in SAP BTP.

1. Exception Handling

There are two main ways to integrate AI into your error handling processes in SAP CI/CPI:

  1. Exception Subprocess: Incorporate Generative AI into an existing integration flow‚Äôs exception subprocess for smooth operation. Read More
  2. Common Exception Handling iFlow: Set up a separate flow dedicated to handling exceptions, where you pass error information from the main flow for centralized handling. Read More

In this example, I have used  exception subprocess approach within a simple integration flow and Google Gemini AI model.

 

2. Understanding Gen-AI Prompt Format and get API Key

For Google Gemini, go to https://aistudio.google.com/prompts/new_chat and click on Get API Key, Create API Key.

Here, you can see the format of the request which is expected by Google Gemini API.

3. Implementation Steps

Following are the steps which I have implemented in Exception Subprocess

1. Content Modifer - Set APIKey & Gen-AI Prompt
To set the API key and content type as requested by Google Gemini

To set the required prompt format, I have created the below exchange properties and externalized it

Value stored in Gen AI prompt is

{     "contents": [       {         "parts": [           {             "text": " You are an SAP Integration consultant skilled in troubleshooting in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI). Above error is persisting while sending the message from sender to receiver system. For this error, Please respond using the following format, with each section clearly separated by a single line break in a direct and professional tone: 1. User-Friendly Error Message: A one sentence error that can be easily understood by non-technical stakeholders 2. Possible Reasons for the Error: List common causes for encountering this error in SAP CPI integration scenarios. 3. Possible Steps to Resolve the Error: Provide possible troubleshooting steps to address the issue and potentially resolve it. 4. HTTP Response: Provide appropriate HTTP error code (numerical value only) to be sent to sender system. "            }         ]       }     ]   }

Note:

All the values are externalized so that, different models like Microsoft Co-pilot or GTP 4 can be used.

2. Groovy script ‚Äì setGenAIPrompt

This script is used to get the error which is caught from the main integration process by the CamelExceptionCaught property, add this error in the prompt to get the tailored response from Gemini and set the prompt structure required by Gemini AI model.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message



def Message processData(Message message) {

    // Retrieve properties from the message

    def camelExceptionCaught = message.getProperty("CamelExceptionCaught")

    def genAIPrompt = message.getProperty("GenAIPrompt")

    def startPrompt = message.getProperty("StartPrompt")



    // Initialize updatedGenAIPrompt as null or empty, it'll be used to set message body eventually

    def updatedGenAIPrompt = null

   

    if (genAIPrompt && startPrompt && camelExceptionCaught) {

        // Find the position of startPrompt in genAIPrompt

        def startIndex = genAIPrompt.indexOf(startPrompt)



        if (startIndex != -1) {

            // Insert space and CamelExceptionCaught after StartPrompt

            updatedGenAIPrompt = genAIPrompt.substring(0, startIndex + startPrompt.length()) +

                                 " " +

                                 camelExceptionCaught +

                                 genAIPrompt.substring(startIndex + startPrompt.length())

                                

            // Set the updatedGenAIPrompt back to a message property

            message.setProperty("UpdatedGenAIPrompt", updatedGenAIPrompt)

        }

    }

   

    if (updatedGenAIPrompt != null) {

        // Set the modified prompt as the message body

        message.setBody(updatedGenAIPrompt)

    }

   

    return message

}

3. Request Reply - Call Google Gemini

I have use HTTP adapter to call Google Gemini
URL: https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.0-flash:generateContent

4. Groovy script ‚Äì captureGenAIResponse

This groovy script is used to capture Custom Error, Possible reason and Possible solution for the error from Gen AI response. Also, handle the errors caused if generative AI is not reachable

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message

import groovy.json.JsonSlurper



def Message processData(Message message) {

    // Retrieve properties

    def captureCustomErrorKey = message.getProperty("CaptureCustomError")

    def capturePossibleReasonKey = message.getProperty("CapturePossibleReason")

    def capturePossibleSolutionKey = message.getProperty("CapturePossibleSolution")

    def captureHTTPCodeKey = message.getProperty("CaptureHTTPCode")  // This should be "HTTP Response:"



    // Get the message body and parse it as JSON

    def payload = message.getBody(String)

    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()



    // Initialize extracted values

    def extractedCustomErrorMessage = null

    def extractedPossibleReason = null

    def extractedPossibleSolution = null

    def extractedPHTTPCode = null



    try {

        // Try parsing the JSON

        def parsedJson = jsonSlurper.parseText(payload)

       

        // Extract the text section from the JSON

        def textContent = parsedJson.candidates[0]?.content?.parts[0]?.text



        if (textContent) {

            // Log the text content to verify structure

            messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)?.addAttachmentAsString("Text Content", textContent, "text/plain")



            // Extract values based on keys

            extractedCustomErrorMessage = extractValueFollowingKey(textContent, captureCustomErrorKey)

            extractedPossibleReason = extractValueFollowingKey(textContent, capturePossibleReasonKey)

            extractedPossibleSolution = extractValueFollowingKey(textContent, capturePossibleSolutionKey)



            // Specifically extract the HTTP response code after "HTTP Response:"

            extractedPHTTPCode = extractHTTPResponseCode(textContent, captureHTTPCodeKey)

        }

    } catch (Exception e) {

        // Log exception and proceed with null outputs

        messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)?.addAttachmentAsString("Exception", e.toString(), "text/plain")

    }



    // Handle extraction results

    message.setProperty("ExtractedCustomErrorMessage", extractedCustomErrorMessage)

    message.setProperty("ExtractedPossibleReason", extractedPossibleReason)

    message.setProperty("ExtractedPossibleSolution", extractedPossibleSolution)

    message.setProperty("ExtractedPHTTPCode", extractedPHTTPCode)

   

    // Set HTTP Code as the message body for demonstration; it will be null if extraction fails

    message.setBody(extractedPHTTPCode)



    return message

}



// Function to extract value that follows a given key in the text content

def extractValueFollowingKey(String textContent, String key) {

    if (key) {

        def keyIndex = textContent.indexOf(key)

        if (keyIndex != -1) {

            def startIndex = keyIndex + key.length()

            if (startIndex != -1) {

                def endIndex = textContent.indexOf("\n\n", startIndex)

                endIndex = endIndex != -1 ? endIndex : textContent.length()



                def extractedText = textContent.substring(startIndex, endIndex).trim()

                extractedText = extractedText.replaceAll('\\*', '')  // Clean up undesired characters

                return extractedText

            }

        }

    }

    return null

}



// Specific extraction utility for HTTP Code.

def extractHTTPResponseCode(String textContent, String key) {

    if (key) {

        def keyIndex = textContent.indexOf(key)

        if (keyIndex != -1) {

            def startIndex = keyIndex + key.length()

            if (startIndex != -1) {

                // Find the end, which is the next newline after the code and description

                def endIndex = textContent.indexOf("\n", startIndex)

                endIndex = endIndex != -1 ? endIndex : textContent.length()



                return textContent.substring(startIndex, endIndex).trim()

            }

        }

    }

    return null

}

 

5. Content Modifier - Set Content Type for Error Response

In this content modifier the header Content-Type is explicitly set if the error response needs to be sent to the sender system.

6. Groovy Script ‚Äì generateErrorResponse

This script is used to log the custom error in the error log, create custom headers and generate an error response if the sender system needs it. I have implemented all the three in this script to show that it is possible.

Based on your requirement, custom error log or custom header or error response can be set.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message



def Message processData(Message message) {

    // Retrieve properties

    def camelExceptionCaught = message.getProperty("CamelExceptionCaught")

    def extractedCustomErrorMessage = message.getProperty("ExtractedCustomErrorMessage")

    def extractedPossibleReason = message.getProperty("ExtractedPossibleReason")

    def extractedPossibleSolution = message.getProperty("ExtractedPossibleSolution")

    def extractedPHTTPCode = message.getProperty("ExtractedPHTTPCode")



    // Set the CamelHttpResponseCode header

    if (extractedPHTTPCode) {

        message.setHeader("CamelHttpResponseCode", extractedPHTTPCode)

    }



    // Create custom headers

    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)

    if (messageLog != null) {

        messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("CustomError", extractedCustomErrorMessage ?: "No custom error message available.")

        messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("PossibleReason", extractedPossibleReason ?: "No possible reason available.")

        messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("PossibleSolution", extractedPossibleSolution ?: "No possible solution available.")

    }



    // Attach extracted values as message attachments

    def possibleReasonAttachment = extractedPossibleReason ?: "No possible reason available."

    def possibleSolutionAttachment = extractedPossibleSolution ?: "No possible solution available."

   

    if (messageLog != null) {

        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("PossibleReason", possibleReasonAttachment, "text/plain")

        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("PossibleSolution", possibleSolutionAttachment, "text/plain")

    }



    // Create dynamic response in XML format

    def responseXml = """<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<Error_Response>

    <SystemError>${camelExceptionCaught}</SystemError>

    <CustomError>${extractedCustomErrorMessage ?: "No custom error message available."}</CustomError>

    <PossibleReason>${extractedPossibleReason ?: "No possible reason available."}</PossibleReason>

    <PossibleSolution>${extractedPossibleSolution ?: "No possible solution available."}</PossibleSolution>

</Error_Response>"""



    // Set XML response as the message body

    message.setBody(responseXml)





if (camelExceptionCaught) {

        throw new Exception("\nSystem Error: ${camelExceptionCaught}\nCustom Error from GenAI: ${extractedCustomErrorMessage ?: 'No custom error message available.'}")

    }



    return message

}

5. Testing

To test, I am using an API client Bruno, which will mimic the sender system. I have maintained the receiver system URL as http://sample.com. So, the message will fail because it is not a valid URL.

 

1. Triggering the iflow from Bruno as shown below

2.  Without Exception Handling using Gen AI, I get the response as below in Bruno as shown below

3. In the iFlow, I have checked Return Exception to Sender under Error Configuration

4. Now, with Exception Handling using Gen AI, I get the response in Bruno as shown below

5. In Cloud Integration Message Monitoring we see that the message is in error

 

6. Error log is as shown below

7. Custom Headers are successful set with Custom Error, Possible Reason and Possible Solution as shown below

8. Attachments are also set with Possible Reason and Possible Solution as shown below

9. If you have a requirement to send the error response with not just custom error from Gen AI but sending possible reason and solution then set the event in the Exception Subprocess as End Message. The only downside is the message in Cloud Integration will be end with status Completed rather than Error.

Go to Groovy Script - generateErrorResponse and comment the lines 46, 47 and 48 which was done to throw custom exception as shown below

In the script, I am setting the appropriate HTTP code for CamelHttpResponseCode from Google Gemini response.

10. When the message is triggered, we can see that the error response is received in Bruno with correct HTTP response code as shown below.

11. If the correct response code is not set from Google Gemini, then HTTP 200 is received in sender system which will be incorrect, and we can‚Äôt identify if the message failed or not without opening the response message

12. Now, if there is an issue with reaching Generative AI then it is handled in Groovy Scripts. For testing, I will use incorrect URL

6. Conclusion

In this blog, I have tried to provide an overview of how we can make use of Generative AI for Exception Handling in SAP Cloud Integration. Of course, the exception subprocess can be improved and tailored as per the requirement in your integration landscape.

Generative AI offers a new way to handle errors in SAP CI/CPI by automating processes that would typically take much longer. By enhancing error handling, businesses can reduce downtime and improve overall efficiency. With the technology constantly advancing, using AI in exception handling can help businesses stay ahead of the curve, making their operations more reliable. Through simple implementation steps, regular testing, and adapting based on feedback, businesses can fully leverage AI for a smarter, more resilient future.

7. Additional Read

Exception Handling in SAP CPI : SAP Help

Whether you have questions about using generative AI for exception handling, experiences to share, or suggestions for improvement, your feedback is invaluable. entry.title: Integration Advisor ‚Äì multi-payload support for MIG creation
entry.content:
Today I would like to share with you another new feature: When creating a Message Implementation Guideline (MIG) based on payload, you can now supply multiple payloads and all payloads are considered together by the application. In this blog post I will provide a short description of this new feature.  

The picture before depicts the overall building blocks of Integration Advisor (of SAP Integration Suite). This blog post mainly relates to the Message Implementation Guideline area.

Short recap: Payload-based creation of MIGs

Earlier this year I had shared with you a larger extension of our payload-based MIG Creation feature. With the extended feature you were able to provide a single payload and choose the MIG nodes that shall get automatically qualified. As a result, each qualifier value  present in the payload will create its own qualification variant in your MIG. Moreover, all nodes present in your payload will get automatically selected and example values are created based on the payload. For more details, please see my earlier blog post: Link 

By the way, this blog post also discussed in detail when you should qualify a MIG node in your MIG structure and when it is better not to qualify.

MIG Creation with multiple payloads

It quite frequently occurs that not all nodes or all qualification variants are present in only one payload. In order to use our payload-based MIG creation in the past, you needed to choose the best fitting payload for automatic consideration and afterwards add missing pieces manually. 

Now we have extended our payload-based MIG generation to also support multiple payloads. In the step Sample Payload  of the Create Message Implementation Guideline wizard you can provide a ZIP file containing multiple payloads. Refer next screenshot for an illustration.

Keep in mind the following technical details:

  • The ZIP file can have a maximum size of 10MB and up-to 25 payloads will be considered.
  • The options SAP Cloud Integration and SAP Process Integration expect XML files as input.
  • The third option EDI Flat File is only available for EDI Type Systems (like ASC X12 or UN/EDIFACT) and requires TXT files.
  • Your ZIP archive might contain other files types (like PDF,  XSD etc.) - these are simply ignored.
  • Your ZIP archive might come with subfolders and all suitable files are extracted from the complete archive.
  • Additionally, the extracted payload files (XML or TXT files depending on your choice) must fit to the Message Type for which you want to create your new MIG. Otherwise these payload files can't be considered.

The MIG Creation wizard now finishes with a pop-up window that summarizes which payloads were successfully applied and which payload files in the ZIP archive were not suitable. For an example refer the screenshot above.

Result of the MIG Creation

All the (successfully processed) payloads will contribute to the automatic customization of your new MIG. More specifically:

  • Qualified nodes: If you have chosen the automatic qualification for a node (in step Select Nodes of the MIG creation wizard), each qualifier value  present in at least one of the payloads will create its own qualification variant.
  • Selection of nodes: A node will automatically get selected in your MIG if the node is used in at least one of your payloads.  

Please note that the option to add Example Values is not available in case of multiple payloads because input from several payloads can't be combined to auto-generate the MIG Example Payload in a meaningful way.  

Conclusion

With this feature extension you can benefit from the payload-based MIG creation even more as it allows you to build your Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs) faster and with less manual effort.
